name: politico
text: The left roared into yesterday's primaries hoping to unseat at least one entrenched Democratic congressman in NYC and derail the Democratic establishment’s pick to face Mitch McConnell in Kentucky https://t.co/PIZa9eNJRE

name: politico
text: But they’re going to have to wait at least a few more days to find out if they succeeded. Even though last night ended without final calls in many of the biggest primaries, the results showed some incumbents in trouble and major trends shaking both parties https://t.co/PIZa9eNJRE

name: politico
text:
Kentucky is poised for a photo finish.

Amy McGrath has a 8-point lead over Charles Booker right now, but her lead is far from secure. Jefferson and Fayette counties won’t release any vote counts until they’ve also tabulated absentee ballots. https://t.co/PIZa9eNJRE https://t.co/P6SX5oBvmm

name: politico
text: The end is near for Rep. Eliot Engel in N.Y. Unless Engel’s supporters are as obsessive about mail voting as he used to be about snagging an aisle seat for the State of the Union address, his time in the House is over. https://t.co/PIZa9eNJRE https://t.co/6jYKkwyCAI

text: It took the coronavirus crisis to persuade the European Union — and especially its German paymaster — that it’s finally time to spend, spend, spend https://t.co/6SQebXKT6t

name: politico
text: The DOJ and state AGs are taking first steps toward a potential antitrust probe of Apple https://t.co/YKDlEOagaD

name: politico
text: 3 people involved in the discussions told us DOJ and the AGs have spoken to several companies unhappy with Apple’s ironclad control of its App Store, the source of frequent griping by developers who say the company’s rules are applied inconsistently https://t.co/YKDlEOagaD

name: politico
text: The discussions have taken place as recently as last week, after European competition officials announced twin probes into Apple’s App Store and its payment platform, Apple Pay https://t.co/YKDlEOagaD

name: politico
text: Developers say Apple unfairly ties access to its App Store with its in-app payment system, which takes a 30 percent cut of most transactions. But the company has varying policies on which apps it requires to pay. https://t.co/YKDlEOagaD

name: politico
text: Companies that offer what the company considers physical goods and services are exempt. Apple maintains that all other digital goods and services, including ones that compete with its own offerings, must use in-app purchase. https://t.co/YKDlEOagaD

name: politico
